history.content:
<md>Different labs and different professors have different standard and needs as to what they want from an undergrad. Here is the advice that I would give to undergrads that want to get into research (feel free for other people to add on). Note that some of these are not mandatory, but just helpful for getting research. Now, these suggestions won't include the obligatory "have research experience" or "know the professor personally" because these aren't really relevant.
1.  Get good grades. This might sound pretty obvious, but for freshmen or sophomores, if you can get a couple of A+'s in your intro courses and really show that you are kicking ass in these undergrad classes, some researchers will definitely show interest, even if you haven't done any kind of ML at all.
2. Get to know your professors. Piggybacking off of the previous point, if you kickass as some class and show real engagement during lecture, discussion, and office hours, the professor might be more open to giving an undergraduate research.
3. Show commitment to a project. Work on some project, any project, and show that you can push through and present some kind of progress or milestone. Plenty of student just have "did research in blah or worked on blah" on their resumes, but if you can show that you accomplished some goal (performance metric or result), this will show that you have the discipline to complete a project. Doesn't even have to be ML, just accomplishing a goal and showing progress is important. 
4. Show genuine interest in a specific field of ML. Plenty of applicants have some kind of vague interest in "ML", "Deep Learning", or "AI". For whomever you are emailing or applying to, show interest in the field that they are working on. Don't just be interested in CV, show interest in, for example, Domain adaptation for Image Segmentation or something. (This point is harder to accomplish, but at least being knowledgeable about a subfield could push you over the edge)
5. Monkey skills. Some researchers just want cheap/free labor. Doesn't even have to be ML skills. Regular Web dev skills or systems or low-level programming are all very helpful and things that graduate students don't want to do. You might have to push through b*tch work for a couple of months, but after that, they might have a project lined up for you to contribute to in a more research related way
6. Networking. Personally speaking, I didn't get my first research opportunity through cold emails. I ended up working for someone who got me recommended to my current research position. This also applies to other people I know got their positions because other people that they worked for (not necessarily in research) were able to vouch for them and get them past the interview. The power of networking is very strong. (Again, not the easiest point to accomplish, but it is important that whoever you work for is a gateway to other potential workplaces and positions)
7. Cast a wide net. Apply to as many people as you can. Find professors, graduate students, research fellows, etc. and just start sending all of them emails. Remember, even if you have sent 100 emails, the people receiving the email will only see 1-2, so don't feel like you are spamming or are doing too much. Worst case scenario, your email is never read and no harm is done.

As for knowledge that people need to know for their labs, it varies lab to lab. Most likely, when you join a new lab, they will throw dozens of papers at you to read and a rabbit hole of papers and conferences and talks to explore. Yes, having some requisite knowledge of the field from classes or blogs or papers is helpful (If you don't know what a "machine learning" is, that might be a bit painful to get through the initial screen), but most people understand that to do actual research (even in a relatively newer field like ML), you need to basically learn multiple years of papers and achievements before you can even start contributing. You can definitely get research without being an expert in ML. TBH URAP isn't an optimal way to get research. That is for groups that have a project lined up for research specifically (to my understanding, someone can correct me if I am wrong here), but plenty of groups have ongoing projects or papers that one can contribute to without going through URAP. I just so happened to know all of the deep learning/ ML topics before getting research, but I know people who got research without taking 188/189/182.</md>

children.subject: +1 to Nick's detailed response. Adding on to 7., I got my first research position over the summer by cold emailing professors like the week before spring finals. It wasn't ML related, and it wasn't even at Berkeley TBH, but cold-emailing is a pretty viable strat.

Don't worry about getting rejected from URAP, as a former undergrad who never got a research position through URAP and still managed to find research opportunities in ML (with a professor who may or may not share a name with a famous athlete) you'll probably be fine. I highly recommend reaching out to grad students: I didn't exactly cold email the grad students I ultimately ended up working with but my research opportunity was a result of networking with grad students in difference capacities. 

You also have to keep in mind, when somebody is deciding on whether or not to take you as a research assistant, they are doing a cost benefit analysis. They need to weigh the cost of getting you up to speed vs the benefit of what you can contribute once you are caught up. You need to make a convincing case as to why you are worth the cost, and the answer has a lot of good points on how to do this. 

As a final point, grad classes are often a good way to network; getting into one is more difficult than a regular class but they often are smaller and give you easier access to the professor or the grad student TA. If you do well enough and impress them, you might be able to find yourself a research position. Some people are even able to turn their final project for a grad topics course into a legitimate research paper with the professor (although this is less common amongst undergrads). Even if you don't get a research position, having grad courses on your transcript will still benefit you in the aforementioned cost-benefit analysis.

history.content:
I’m a rising junior studying CS + math looking for my first research position (mainly interested in CV, although tbh I’m interested in most ML related fields). I’ve done well in 126 and 127 (taking 189 this fall) and have an ok technical gpa (3.7) but have literally no internship and research experience, so I’m wondering if it’s even possible for me to land a research position for the summer or upcoming fall. I’ve been rejected from URAP every semester I’ve applied and people have recommended that I cold email grad students but it’s hard to believe that this will do anything considering I can’t even get into URAP lol. 


For those of you doing ML related work: how were you able to get your first position? Did you spend a ton of time self studying/reading research papers? Did you just understand stuff like CNNs, transformers, etc at a high level or were you consistently keeping up/implementing papers on your own and knew the ins and outs of your field? Is it possible to get research with just basic ML knowledge/high level understanding of a lab’s papers?
history.subject: Getting 1st research position
